I was testing this new reintroduction with 3DoF headsets and I think we are adding scope.userHeight twice. Because poseObject equals camera and we are adding 'poseObject.position.set( 0, scope.userHeight, 0 );' when pose.position is null and besides, we are adding the standingMatrix that is 'standingMatrix.makeTranslation(0, scope.userHeight, 0);' when stageParameters are null.

To try to clarify it, because now doesn't work as expected in all cases:

If we have the world position of a camera placed on for example: x=0, y=1, z=0, whether or not it has a parent. What is the expected behaviour in each case?

If we start from this proposal where we place the camera to render correctly located for Desktop/(Magic Window or Fullscreen desktop mode, I'm not sure how to call it properly)/3DoF:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5744112/35472027-e61ba270-0367-11e8-95e7-09f0058e5472.png)


...we would need to add something outside the WebXRManager to have a correct camera position on 6DoF headset, if not we would have the camera at 1 + 1.6 meters (or the real height of the user if we have stageParameters) from the floor.

Because I think doesn't have sense to start with the camera at 0,0,0. Or am I missing something?

@arturitu In your schema above the height is always given by `userHeight` if a headset does not have `stageParameters`. That will cover all the use cases where a headset pose is available: 3DOF, 6DOF, Magic Window. For the 2D / Desktop case the `WebVRManager` plays no part and the height has to be set by the application. A-Frame covers that use case by saving the position on the camera when entering VR and restoring it when exiting. If you do something like this:
`<a-camera position="0 1.6 0">` The camera will be placed at 1.6m from the ground in all the cases you describe if there are no stageParameters. In the case of present `stageParameters` the `sittingToStandingTransform` will be used. I hope it is a bit more clear.
Thanks!
